journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Reinforced Plastics and Composites

title-group.article-title: Damping research of fiber-reinforced resin mineral composite-based micromechanical modeling

contrib-group.aff: Key Laboratory of High Efficiency and Clean Mechanical Manufacture, Ministry of Education of China, School of Mechanical Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan, China

author-notes.corresp: Jianhua Zhang, Key Laboratory of High Efficiency and Clean Mechanical Manufacture, Ministry of Education of China, School of Mechanical Engineering, Shandong University, 17923 Jingshi Road, Jinan, 250061, China. Email: jhzhang@sdu.edu.cn

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Compared with cast iron and welded steel, fiber-reinforced resin mineral composite has better damping property that it can be used to produce precision machine tool beds in order to better satisfy the requirement of vibration alleviating. Suppose that the distribution of fibers in fiber-reinforced resin mineral composite is homogeneous, the damping model of single fiber is built on the basis of energy dissipation theory and the direction efficiency coefficient is defined as a new parameter to indicate the influence of single fiber’s orientation to the damping property of fiber-reinforced resin mineral composite. Typical fiber-reinforced resin mineral composite samples with different component ratio and surface treatment of fibers are prepared and their damping ratio is measured to validate the aforementioned assumptions. Research results show that the damping performance is better with longer fiber and lower interfacial bonding strength.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: With the development of high-precision machining, vibration generated in the machining process has much more influence on the dimensional precision and surface quality of workpiece, how to minimize vibration is now a more important factor than before. The machine tool bed is a basic component in high-precision machine tools that it plays an important role in vibration alleviating. Cast iron and welded steel are the most widely used materials; although acceptable in the past, they can no longer meet the requirement of high-precision machining. The development of new materials with excellent damping property to produce machine tool bed is an effective way to improve overall performance.1,2

Using natural granite particles as aggregate and organic resin as binder, resin mineral composite (RMC) is a new material that is prepared under normal temperature. Compared with cast iron and welded steel, RMC has ten times the damping ratio that it can better absorb vibrations generated in the machining process, especially in high-precision machining processes. However, the application of RMC is restricted by its limitation in mechanical strength. So, adding fibers to reinforce RMC has become one of the hot topics for researchers now.3–6

Compared with the reinforced mechanical strength, the use of fibers also produces a certain effect to the damping performance of RMC inevitably. Therefore, related scholars all over the world have conducted a series of research on the damping mechanism of fiber-reinforced resin mineral composite (FRRMC). EI-Gamal7 investigate the effect of different parameters on the bond performance of near surface-mounted fiber strengthening technique, such as adhesive type, groove size and so on. Lee8 manufactured a hybrid column by adhesively bonding glass fiber-reinforced epoxy composite plates to a cast iron column. The damping capacity was calculated with respect to the fiber orientation and thickness of the composite laminate by the Ross-Kerwin-Ungar (R.K.U) equation. His experimental results show that the damping capacity of the hybrid column was 35% higher than that of the cast iron column. Kyriazoglou9 described a method consisting of experimental identification of damping, using vibration damping testing methods and utilization of finite element analysis (FEA), which can be applied to homogeneous materials. Melo10 investigate the effect of fiber volume fraction on the energy absorption capacity of fiber-reinforced composite materials by using dynamic mechanical analysis measurements. Chandra11 incorporates some micromechanical investigations for the prediction of damping coefficients of two-phase continuous fiber-reinforced composite.

For excellent vibration alleviating property, FRRMC would be a suitable material to produce elementary machine tool parts. The effect of using fiber on damping performance needs to be investigated systematically. Suppose that the distribution of fibers in FRRMC is homogeneous, the damping model of single fiber is built in this paper on the basis of energy dissipation theory and the direction efficiency coefficient is defined as a new parameter to indicate the influence of single fiber’s orientation to the damping property of FRRMC. Typical FRRMC samples with different component ratio and surface treatment of fibers are prepared and their damping ratio is measured to get the influence of different component to the damping property of FRRMC.

sec.title: Modeling
sec.p: FRRMC is a typical viscoelastic material that the strain applied on it always lags behind stress as a result of viscosity. The relationship between strain and stress ceases to appear to a straight line but to a hysteresis loop. The area of the hysteresis loop is equal to energy dissipated as heat energy or by any other way in an oscillation cycle. Interior energy dissipation produced by molecule function within resin and fiber is the main influence factor to damping property, while interfacial energy dissipation produced by debonding failure plays an additional role.

According to the relationship definition between damping ratio and tangent of hysteretic angle,12 damping loss factor can be defined as: (1)ψ=ΔWW=2πtanφ=4πξ where ψ is the energy loss factor and ξ is the damping ratio; ΔW is the dissipated energy and W is the total energy stored; φ is the hysteretic angle.

Just as shown in Figure 1, suppose that the distribution of fibers in FRRMC is homogeneous and the total dissipated energies of composite consist of energy dissipated by fibers, energy dissipated by resin and energy dissipated by interfacial debonding, namely, there is no clustering nor winding, the damping model of single fiber is built on the basis of energy dissipation theory and the direction efficiency coefficient is defined as a new parameter to indicate the influence of single fiber’s orientation to the damping property of FRRMC. Figure 1.
Damping model of single fiber.

As fiber and resin matrix are both viscoelastic materials, parts of the strain energies during deformation are dissipated. Suppose the energy dissipated is roughly proportional to the total strain energy, damping loss factor in the micromechanical model of single fiber based on energy dissipation and energy balance theory is defined as below: (2)ψa=ψfWf+ψmWm+WcWf+Wm+Wc where, ψa represents the total damping loss factor in the model of single fiber under only axial stress; ψf and ψm represent dissipation factor of fiber and resin, respectively; Wf and Wm are the strain energy of fiber and resin under the stress F; Wc represents energy produced by friction at the interface between fiber and resin.

Then, the interfacial damping loss factor ψc can be defined as below: (3)ψc=WcWf+Wm+Wc where, (4){Wf=1/1 22∫VfσfɛfdVWm=1/1 22∫VmσmɛmdV where, ɛf and ɛm represent strain of fiber and resin, Vf and Vm are the volume of fiber and resin. Suppose only interface slip occurs between fiber and resin but no broken fiber appears, then (5)F=Efɛf=Emɛm where, Ef and Em are the Young's modulus of fiber and resin. Substituting equations (3), (4) and (5) into equation (2) yields: (6)ψa=ψfKfVf+ψmKmVmKfVf+KmVm+Wc+ψc where, (7)Kf=12Fɛf,Km=12Fɛm

As fibers are randomly orientated, the distribution model of fiber in spherical coordinates is built as shown in Figure 2. The radius of the model is equal to the length of fiber used in the composite. According to the theory of statistical probability, the orientation of fiber is subject to uniform distribution. The distribution probability of fibers falls into a scope that at an angle θ to the Z-axis and at an angle ϕ to the X-axis can be expressed as the ratio of infinitesimal's area to hemisphere's area. (8)f(θ,ϕ)dθdϕ=r2sinθdθdϕ2πr2=12πsinθdθdϕ Figure 2.
Distribution model in spherical coordinates.
The direction coefficient of fiber in three-dimensional damping model can be calculated as (9)ηθ=∫0π∫0π/2f(θ,ϕ)dθdϕ=12π∫0π∫0π/2sinθdθdϕ=12
Then, substituting equation (9) into equation (6), the damping loss factor is revised to (10)ψ=ηθψa=12ψfKfVf+ψmKmVmKfVf+KmVm+Wc+12ψc

sec.title: Preparation of samples
sec.p: The aggregates used in the test are granite particles produced in Jinan, China. These aggregates were classified into five groups according to their diameters in order to maximize compactness. The epoxy resin applied is 615A whose epoxy value is 0.547, stabilizer is ethylenediamine and flexibilizer is dibutyl phthalate (DBP). Acetone is used as the diluent to make the liquid composite less mucous. Glass fiber is used as the reinforced fiber whose length ranges from 5 mm to 25 mm. The mass fraction of fiber and resin are kept constant during designing experiments.

A series of FRRMC samples are prepared in cube form with length, width and height of 100 mm each, respectively. The surfaces of glass fibers were ultrasonic cleaned before adding into the RMC. The preparation of FRRMC samples composed of the composite forming process and machining process after the sample is formed. Solidification of epoxy resin is exothermic, and so the moisture among the granite particles may cause too many air bubbles. Thus, the granite particles are dried before weighing. Both liquid and solid raw materials are mixed evenly, and then mixed together to set on the vibration table. Vibration lasted during the whole mixing process, and continued for another 20 min after the mixing process ended. All the FRRMC samples are cured in standard curing room with the constant temperature of 20℃.

sec.title: Damping property testing
sec.p: Under existing conditions, it is difficult to measure the damping loss factor of composite directly.13 So, the resonance frequency method is adopted based on the relationship between damping loss factor and damping ratio as shown in equation (1), which is shown as below: (11)ξ=1-(fv/fa)22 where, fv and fa are the resonance frequency in the amplitude frequency diagram of velocity and acceleration, respectively.

As it is shown in Figure 3, instruments for damping property testing include the impact hammer, INV3018C multichannel data collecting device, INV9823 acceleration transducer and INV1861 charge amplifier. Figure 3.
Diagram of measuring process.

sec.title: Influence of fiber dosage and fiber length to damping
sec.p: Granite particles, resin and glass fibers are the key component in FRRMC, however, as the proportion of granite particles used in RMC is more than 80% and they are almost close to the rigid body, namely, they have no vibration alleviating property. So, the glass fibers and resin used in FRRMC play an important role in damping performance than the other components. Meanwhile, compared with RMC, glass fiber is used here as the reinforced fiber whose damping ratio is far bigger than RMC. So, as is shown in Figure 5, with the increase of the mass fraction of fibers, the damping ratio of typical samples increased too, which is consistent to the damping model in equation (10).

However, as it is shown in Figure 4, if the fiber dosage exceeds 8%, a serious clustering phenomenon occurs due to the existing Van Der Waals Force between fibers and the winding in stirring process. Then, a series of interface defects such as broken fibers and holes in the interface between fiber and resin emerge. Although the effect of interface defect is similar to weaker interfacial bonding, it cannot refill the damping property, which leads to a decrease in the damping ratio of the composite. Figure 4.
Clustering phenomenon of glass fibers.
Figure 5.
Influence of fiber dosage to damping property.

In conclusion, although the quantitative expression in equation (10) shows a proportional relationship between damping loss factor and fiber dosage cannot increase unlimitedly, thus, other factors need to be considered in practical processing.

sec.title: Influence of resin dosage to damping
sec.p:
Resin is main material whose damping ratio is far bigger than the other components. So, the mass fraction of resin used in RMC plays an important role in the damping property. As is shown in Figure 6, with the increase of the mass fraction of resin, the damping ratio of typical samples increased too, which is consistent to the damping model in equation (10). Figure 6.
Influence of resin dosage to damping property.

sec.title: Influence of surface treatment fibers to damping
sec.p:
In order to get the influence of interfacial bonding-to-damping ratio, two groups of samples are manufactured. The mass fraction of fibers used here is 5% and each sample is measured three times then takes an average. Fibers used in group A are for cleansing process only. Fibers used in group B are marinated in solutions of silane coupling agent for about 20 min, so that more chemical radicals could be formed on their surfaces. As shown in Figures 7 and 8, fibers in sample A are smooth while fibers in sample B are rough, which means that more resin bond to the fibers, and sample B has a better interfacial bonding strength. Each damping ratio test is measured three times and then the mean value is calculated. As is shown in Table 1, the mean damping ratio of sample A is 0.2534, which is better than that of sample B. Figure 7.
Samples without surface treatment fibers.
Figure 8.
Samples with surface treatment fibers.
Table 1.
Experimental result of different surface treatment.
Surface treatment method Ultrasonic cleaning Marinated by Silane coupling agent
Damping ratio (ξ) 0.2534 0.2316

Although the surface treatment of fibers play an important role in the damping property of FRRMC, this pretreatment cannot be left out for its better influence to the mechanical property of FRRMC. Balance should be gained between mechanical property and damping property in the practical application.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
Based on the results and discussion obtained in the present work, the following main summary remarks and conclusions can be drawn.
Suppose that the distribution of fibers in FRRMC is homogeneous, the damping model between single fiber and resin is proposed. Result indicates that the influence of single fiber’s orientation to the total damping property of FRRMC accounts for half of its work and the direction coefficient of fibers in three-dimensional damping model is 0.5.
Glass fibers and resin used in RMC play an important role in damping performance than the other components. However, for their less mass fraction, the work of glass fibers is inferior to the work of resin, and the resin plays the most important role in vibration alleviating.
Single factor experiments of fiber dosage are adopted to validate above assumptions. Research results show that the damping performance is better with more fibers and weaker interface bonding strength.

sec.p: The work of this paper is supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant No. 51175308) and the National Science and Technology Major Project of China (Grant No. 2012ZX04010032).
